page.title: The Plant
page.subtitle: Taxonomy, nomenclature, and the relationship between Piper methysticum and its wild ancestor.

intro.paragraph1: Piper methysticum is no ordinary crop plant. It is the result of millennia of human selection and exists today exclusively as a cultivated form. Wild populations no longer exist – every Kava plant in the world is a clone passed down by human hands.

taxonomie.title: Taxonomic Classification
taxonomie.intro: Kava belongs to the Piperaceae family (pepper plants), one of the oldest flowering plant families. This family comprises about 3,600 species in 5 genera, including the well-known black pepper (Piper nigrum).
taxonomie.forster: The first scientific description was made in 1786 by Johann Georg Adam Forster, a German naturalist who accompanied James Cook on his second voyage around the world. Forster documented the plant and its use on the Pacific islands.

name.title: Meaning of the Name
name.intro: The scientific name Piper methysticum is a combination of Latin and Greek:

piper.title: Piper
piper.description: Latin for "pepper". Refers to the plant's membership in the pepper family and the slightly pungent taste of the root.

methysticum.title: methysticum
methysticum.description: From the Greek μεθυστικός (methystikos) = "intoxicating" or "causing drunkenness". Describes the psychoactive effect of the plant.

localNames.intro: The name "Kava" itself comes from the Austronesian languages of the Pacific. Different names exist in various regions:

wichmannii.title: Piper wichmannii – The Wild Ancestor
wichmannii.intro: The closest relative of Piper methysticum is Piper wichmannii, considered the wild ancestor of today's cultivated Kava. This species occurs naturally in Papua New Guinea, the Solomon Islands, and northern Vanuatu.
wichmannii.alert: Important: Piper wichmannii is sometimes called "Wild Kava" and consumed locally. However, it contains a different kavalactone profile and is considered less tolerable than cultivated noble Kava varieties.

differences.title: Differences between P. methysticum and P. wichmannii

domestikation.title: Domestication & Evolution
domestikation.intro: The domestication of Kava likely began about 3,000 years ago in northern Vanuatu. Genetic studies show that Piper methysticum evolved from Piper wichmannii through repeated hybridization and polyploidization.
domestikation.changes: The domestication process led to several crucial changes:

polyploidie.title: Increased Polyploidy
polyploidie.description: While P. wichmannii is diploid (2n = 26), P. methysticum is decaploid (2n = 130). This multiplication of the chromosome set led to larger roots and higher kavalactone content.

fertilitaet.title: Loss of Fertility
fertilitaet.description: The high polyploidy led to sterility. The plant produces flowers but no viable seeds. This made it completely dependent on humans.

wirkprofil.title: Optimized Effect Profile
wirkprofil.description: Through targeted selection, varieties with more pleasant effects and better tolerability were preferred. This led to the development of today's "noble Kava" varieties.

sortenvielfalt.title: Variety Diversity
sortenvielfalt.description: Today, over 80 documented cultivars exist in Vanuatu alone. Each variety has a unique chemotype profile and characteristic effect properties.

kulturgut.title: Kava as Living Cultural Heritage
kulturgut.paragraph1: Since Kava cannot reproduce on its own, every plant existing today is the result of an unbroken chain of human transmission. Cuttings have been passed from generation to generation, from family to family, from village to village.

quote.text: Kava is thus one of the oldest documented examples of consciously selective agriculture in the South Pacific. The plant is a living cultural heritage – passed down from generation to generation.
quote.author: Sebastian Freidank, "Kava – Root of Calm"

kulturgut.paragraph2: In the countries of origin, Kava is not just seen as a crop plant, but often as a living being – with name, character, and history. It is not uncommon for individual plants to be named and revered in rituals. This deep connection between humans and plant is what makes Kava not only effective but also meaningful.
kulturgut.paragraph3: The dependence on humans also has a dark side: Without continuous cultivation, Piper methysticum would become extinct within a generation. This underscores the responsibility that comes with growing and trading Kava.
